questions.explanation: You will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement, or lose an existing endorsement, if you renounce your U.S. citizenship; are not a lawful permanent U.S. resident; are wanted for, indicted for, or convicted of certain felonies; are judged mentally defective or are committed to a mental institution; or are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to pose a security threat.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: Off-ramps:
questions.answerC: Should not be used by trucks.
questions.answerD: Should be used only if following another vehicle.
questions.explanation: The combination of slopes and curves can make freeway on- and off-ramps dangerous for trucks. Remember that posted speed limits on ramps may be safe to be driven by cars but too fast to be driven by large or heavily-loaded vehicles.

questions.question: A driver can have:
questions.answerA: Two licenses, one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.answerC: A license for each state in which they plan to drive.
questions.answerD: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one license. States share driver data through a computer database to prevent the issuance of duplicate licenses.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: If stopped on the road or shoulder, within 10 minutes, you must:
questions.answerC: Stand behind your vehicle and motion for traffic to pass you.
questions.explanation: If stopped on the side of the road, you must place emergency warning devices, such as reflective warning triangles, within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Why should the steps of a pre-trip inspection be done in the same order each time?
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget a step.
questions.answerD: The form must be followed in order.
questions.explanation: Doing an inspection the same way every time will help you learn the necessary steps. You will be less likely to forget a step if you get into a routine.

questions.question: A vehicle should be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Warning devices for parked vehicles, such as flares.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicles should always carry the proper emergency equipment. Be sure your vehicle is equipped with at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses, unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers; and warning devices for parked vehicles, such as warning triangles, fuses, or liquid burning flares.

questions.question: When an engine is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should come on and then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need seven to eight hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a person being drowsy?
questions.explanation: Driving drowsy is dangerous and should always be avoided. Warning signs of drowsiness include frequent blinking, your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, frequent yawning, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: If a bus has a restroom, the restroom must include:
questions.explanation: The restroom on a bus must be equipped with an emergency buzzer.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror:
questions.answerA: Allows the driver to see what is happening inside of the bus.
questions.answerB: Allows the driver to see what is happening outside of the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: At railroad crossings, bus drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not need to stop, but must reduce their speed to 25 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Do not need to stop, but must open the door to listen for trains.
questions.answerD: Must stop and check for any approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: Buses must never carry ____ in the space occupied by passengers.
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in the area occupied by passengers.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to result in the most student deaths per year?
questions.answerA: Students loading and unloading a school bus
questions.answerD: Accidents in which drivers ignore traffic signals or signs
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year while getting on or off school buses than while riding as passengers on board school buses.

questions.question: When passengers ride a bus:
questions.answerA: Leaving items in the aisle is acceptable.
questions.answerB: Leaving items in the aisle is acceptable while everyone is seated.
questions.answerC: There should be no obstacles in the aisle.
questions.answerD: An item may be left in the aisle if there is an orange cone beside it.
questions.explanation: Do not allow passengers to leave any items in an aisle while the bus is moving. Aisles and stairwells should always be free of obstructions.

questions.question: Before driving a bus that has been left unattended:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be thoroughly washed.
questions.answerB: Air should be removed from tires.
questions.answerC: The interior should be checked for damage.
questions.answerD: The driver should look for any animals that may have gotten onboard.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. When inspecting a bus that has been left unattended, you should do a walkthrough to check the interior for damage.

questions.question: The area to the left of a school bus is considered especially dangerous to students because:
questions.answerA: The sun’s reflection obscures the left side of the bus.
questions.answerB: Passing vehicles are located to the left of the bus.
questions.answerC: It is difficult to see the left side of any bus.
questions.answerD: There is no door on the left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: While all sides of a school bus have danger zones, the left side is particularly hazardous to students due to the presence of passing vehicles.

questions.question: Before driving a bus, you must:
questions.answerA: Review its most recent inspection report.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: Before operating a bus, you should ensure that it is safe by:
questions.answerA: Reviewing the inspection report left by the previous driver.
questions.answerC: Asking your supervisor if the bus seems safe.
questions.answerD: Asking passengers if they are comfortable.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume you'll hear an approaching train.
questions.answerB: Rely solely on signals to tell you if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Open the door and listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Immediately proceed after a train has passed.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.explanation: While some kinds of hazardous materials may be carried on a bus under certain conditions, tear gas and irritating materials must never be carried. Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D and emergency medical supplies are permitted.

questions.question: How many classes of hazardous materials are there?
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: If a bus has a brake and accelerator interlock system, the system should:
questions.answerA: Be turned off in most situations.
questions.answerB: Only be used in inclement weather.
questions.answerC: Never be used in place of the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Urban transit buses may have a brake and accelerator interlock system, which applies the brakes and holds the throttle in an idle position while the rear door is open. This system should not be used as a substitute for the parking brake.

questions.question: If driving a charter bus, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Tell passengers how to operate the TVs, if equipped.
questions.answerB: Not allow passengers to board until the scheduled departure time.
questions.answerC: Allow passengers to board early to get ahead of schedule.
questions.answerD: Tell passengers to fill the back of the bus first.
questions.explanation: To help prevent theft or vandalism, charter bus drivers should not allow passengers to board the vehicle until the scheduled departure time.

questions.question: The loading of a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: Drivers should try to stop ____ away from students at a bus stop.
questions.explanation: A school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from students who are being picked up at a bus stop. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, allowing the driver to observe their movements and better monitor their locations.

questions.question: If you miss a student’s stop while bringing students home after school, you should:
questions.answerD: Stop quickly and let them exit.
questions.explanation: If a school bus driver forgets to stop where a student is meant to unload, the driver should not back up to the stop. Instead, they should follow established local procedures.

questions.question: Rules regarding passenger comfort, such as smoking guidelines, should:
questions.answerA: Not be mentioned unless there is a rule violation.
questions.answerB: Only be mentioned if a passenger specifically asks about something.
questions.answerC: Be announced at the start of the trip.
questions.answerD: Be discussed individually with each passenger.
questions.explanation: Many charter and intercity carriers have rules about passengers smoking, drinking, and using music players while on the bus. Explaining passenger rules at the start of a trip is often an effective way to avoid trouble later on.

questions.question: The stairwell of a bus:
questions.answerA: Can be used to store items, if needed.
questions.answerB: Can be used as a seat, if needed.
questions.answerC: Should be used to store small items.
questions.answerD: Must remain clear at all times.
questions.explanation: The aisles and stairwell of a bus must be kept clear at all times. Do not let passengers use these areas to store additional baggage.

questions.question: In general, a disabled bus with passengers still on board:
questions.answerA: Should be pushed by another bus.
questions.answerB: Should not be pushed by another bus.
questions.explanation: A disabled bus with riders on board should not be towed or pushed by another vehicle, unless it would be unsafe for the passengers to exit the bus in the location where it is stranded. If that is the case, the bus may be towed or pushed to a safe location for passengers to exit the bus.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: How many classes of hazardous materials are there?
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: An outside convex mirror is properly adjusted if:
questions.answerA: The driver can see at least one lane of traffic and the entire side of the bus.
questions.answerB: The driver can see the front bumper.
questions.answerC: The driver can see the top of the bus.
questions.answerD: The driver can see the front windshield.
questions.explanation: The outside right and left side convex mirrors on a school bus should be positioned so that the driver can see the fronts of the rear tires touching the ground; each side of the bus up to the mirror mounts; and at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus.

questions.question: When arriving at a destination, a bus driver should:
questions.answerC: Wait to make announcements until the bus has stopped and passengers are exiting.
questions.answerD: Remind exiting passengers to take their belongings.
questions.explanation: When arriving at a final destination or intermediate stop, a bus driver should remind passengers to take their belongings with them when exiting the bus. It is best for the driver to make this announcement before the bus comes to a complete stop.

questions.question: Drivers should try to stop ____ away from students at a bus stop.
questions.explanation: A school bus should stop at least 10 feet away from students who are being picked up at a bus stop. This forces the students to walk toward the bus, allowing the driver to observe their movements and better monitor their locations.

questions.question: At railroad crossings, bus drivers:
questions.answerB: Do not need to stop, but must reduce their speed to 25 mph below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Do not need to stop, but must open the door to listen for trains.
questions.answerD: Must stop and check for any approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: What do outside crossover mirrors allow a driver to see?
questions.answerC: The right side of the bus
questions.answerD: The left side of the bus
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a school bus driver see the danger zone area directly in front of the bus, as well as the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: Buses should never transport:
questions.explanation: Buses must never transport labeled radioactive materials in the space occupied by people. Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D, emergency hospital supplies, and medications are allowed.

questions.question: The driver’s seat of a bus should include:
questions.answerA: A pocket for storage on its left side.
questions.answerB: A pocket for storage on its right side.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus must be equipped with a seat belt, which the driver should always use.

questions.question: When planning to drive a bus that has been parked for a few days:
questions.answerA: The driver should assume the interior is in good working order.
questions.answerB: The driver should call the local police department.
questions.answerC: The driver should do a walkthrough inspection to ensure no damage has occurred since the last trip.
questions.answerD: The driver should ask the passengers to check the interior of the bus.
questions.explanation: People sometimes damage unattended buses. Before driving a bus that has been unattended, you should check the interior to confirm that everything is in proper condition.

questions.question: Carry-on luggage should be:
questions.answerB: Kept on the laps of the passengers.
questions.answerD: Secured in a way that allows the driver to move freely and easily.
questions.explanation: On a bus, all baggage and freight must be stored in a manner that allows the driver to move freely and easily; allows riders to exit by any window or door in the event of an emergency; and protects riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: If your bus's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) stops working:
questions.answerA: You will not have any working brakes.
questions.answerB: The brakes will react more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: You will still have normal braking power.
questions.explanation: If its Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working, a vehicle will still retain its normal braking power. The driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal fashion.

questions.question: Many carriers have passenger and safety rules. To avoid issues with passengers reacting to these rules, you should:
questions.answerB: Not have passengers sit next to each other.
questions.answerC: Have passengers who may want to smoke sit next to each other.
questions.answerD: Explain the rules at the start of the trip.
questions.explanation: Many charter and intercity carriers have rules about passengers smoking, drinking, and using music players while on the bus. Explaining passenger rules at the start of a trip is often an effective way to avoid trouble later on.

questions.question: An emergency roof hatch:
questions.answerA: Must always be locked down before traveling.
questions.answerB: May be left partially open while traveling to allow for the movement of fresh air.
questions.answerC: Should never be opened, except in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Should always be open while traveling.
questions.explanation: While emergency roof hatches on buses may be locked in partially-open positions to allow for the movement of fresh air, do not leave them open as a regular practice. It is important to remember that having a hatch open gives the bus a slightly higher clearance.

questions.question: One reason for you to sign a previous driver’s vehicle inspection report is if:
questions.answerA: The previous driver dated their entry.
questions.answerB: Reported defects are certified to have been repaired.
questions.answerC: You plan to drive for longer than one hour or travel farther than 50 miles.
questions.answerD: The report is left on the dashboard.
questions.explanation: You should only sign a previous inspection report if defects were either noted and certified to have been repaired or if repairs were not needed.

questions.question: The emergency exit door:
questions.answerA: Can be opened if the bus becomes too hot while being driven.
questions.answerB: Can be opened while the bus is being driven if the bus is carrying cargo.
questions.answerC: Can be opened to provide a better view while the bus is being backed.
questions.answerD: Should never be open while the bus is being driven.
questions.explanation: Check all emergency exits before operating a bus. Never drive a bus with an open emergency exit door or window.

questions.question: When should you inspect the mirrors on a bus?
questions.answerD: Is not necessary to inspect the mirrors.
questions.explanation: The mirrors of a bus should always be inspected before a trip. Adjust them as necessary before beginning to drive.

questions.question: If you are transporting Class 3 flammable liquids and your cargo needs to be moved into another tank, the flammable liquids:
questions.answerA: May be transferred on the roadway as long as no other people are nearby.
questions.answerB: Should not be transferred on a public road, unless under emergency circumstances.
questions.answerC: Should be kept secret when they are being moved to another tank.
questions.explanation: Flammable liquids should not be transferred from one vehicle to another on a public roadway, unless being moved due to an emergency. Always warn others of the hazards presented by the materials.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: A HazMat endorsement is valid for:
questions.explanation: While a regular CDL is valid for eight years, a HazMat endorsement is valid for only five years after the date the DMV receives notification that your background test has been passed.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: What shape is a placard indicating hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: How is a hazardous materials warning presented?
questions.answerB: By wrapping the package in orange
questions.answerC: By placing the item away from other cargo and covering it with a sign
questions.explanation: Signs are placed on the outside of vehicles and bulk packages to warn drivers and others about hazardous materials. These diamond-shaped signs are known as "placards."

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the items can be distinguished by:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials being listed first.
questions.answerB: The non-hazardous materials being written in pencil.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials being listed in red ink.
questions.answerD: The hazardous materials being written larger than the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: Before any flammable liquids are loaded or unloaded, the engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many products classed as poison are also flammable. Take the appropriate precautions if you think your cargo may be flammable.

questions.question: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes:
questions.answerA: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper if a small piece of paper is being used.
questions.answerB: Should be abbreviated on a shipping paper to make them easier to read.
questions.answerC: Should not be abbreviated on a shipping paper.
questions.answerD: Should only be abbreviated on a shipping paper if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: Identification numbers, shipping names, and hazard classes must never be abbreviated when listed on a shipping paper. The only exception to this is if the abbreviation is specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You can proceed without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: You can proceed without stopping if no other vehicles are within sight.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, the driver:
questions.answerA: Can cross railroad tracks without slowing or stopping.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching railroad tracks, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at railroad crossings before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Should never drive over railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials must always be stopped before being driven over railroad tracks, even if the tanks are empty.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: Where on a truck should placards be placed?
questions.answerB: On the left and right sides
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: As a resource to police and firefighters, the National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, what letters will appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.explanation: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: What should be done if the third column of the Hazardous Materials Table contains the word “Forbidden?”
questions.answerA: The indicated substance should not be transported.
questions.answerB: The indicated substance should be transported by air.
questions.answerC: The indicated substance should only be transported at night.
questions.answerD: The indicated substance should be accompanied by a security guard.
questions.explanation: The third column of the Hazardous Materials Table lists items' hazard classes and divisions. Drivers should never transport a material that is marked by the word "Forbidden."

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: Unless it is clearly unsafe, what does a driver need to accept a package?
questions.explanation: When the shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials become more dangerous when exposed to heat. Hazardous materials should be loaded and unloaded away from heat sources.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the items can be distinguished by:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials being listed first.
questions.answerB: The non-hazardous materials being written in pencil.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials being listed in red ink.
questions.answerD: The hazardous materials being written larger than the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, what letters will appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.explanation: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: Before any flammable liquids are loaded or unloaded, the engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump.

questions.question: Hazardous materials laws are controlled by:
questions.explanation: Because of the risks presented by the nature of the materials, government on federal, state, and local levels may impose regulations on the transportation of hazardous materials.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, they must be placed on all four sides of the transporting vehicle.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: When loading or unloading explosive materials, you should:
questions.answerC: Use sharp-pointed tools to open the packages.
questions.explanation: Always turn off your vehicle's engine before loading or unloading explosive materials. Never drop, throw, or roll packages containing explosives.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package:
questions.answerB: Has been prepared in compliance with the rules.
questions.answerC: Was packed at a specific location.
questions.answerD: Will be placed on the trailer first.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they are certifying that the package has been prepared in accordance with its applicable rules.

questions.question: Your engine runs a pump used during the delivery of compressed gas. After delivery, you should turn off the engine ____ unhooking the hoses.
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: Can only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerD: Can be driven if it does not contain radioactive materials.
questions.explanation: A vehicle carrying hazardous materials must be appropriately placarded to be driven. An improperly placarded vehicle may only be driven if necessary to protect life or property in an emergency.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Drive to find a phone to alert emergency personnel
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean up facility
questions.answerC: Park the vehicle and contact emergency personnel
questions.explanation: In the event of a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, do not continue to drive any longer than is necessary for safety. Continuing to drive would result in a larger area becoming contaminated. Instead, park the vehicle, secure the area, stay with the vehicle, and send someone to get help.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: If cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.answerD: Spray the leaking containers with water.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should:
questions.answerB: Be used only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Be used together with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve works the trailer brakes but should only be used when testing them. Using it while driving could create a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) can be identified by:
questions.answerA: A sticker on the control panel.
questions.answerB: A yellow lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: The letters "ABS" on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: A metal plate on the inside of the driver’s side door.
questions.explanation: You can tell that your vehicle is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) if it has a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of their way.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing to do is try to get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact with the driver and do not let yourself be provoked by gestures. Do not try to challenge aggressive drivers by speeding up.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: In a double or triple, the more heavily-loaded trailer should be immediately behind the tractor.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: If a tire rim is damaged, it should be:
questions.answerD: Put on the axle farthest from the driver.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are not safe.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: If something is found to be unsafe during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue with the trip and make an appointment with a mechanic after the trip is completed.
questions.answerB: Let a more experienced driver use the truck.
questions.answerD: Not use the items found to be unsafe, but may continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals anything unsafe about your vehicle, you must get it repaired. It is illegal to operate an unsafe vehicle.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) uses a ____ light to warn that the system is not working properly.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: Driving too fast:
questions.answerA: Is a major cause of fatal crashes.
questions.answerB: Can be a good way to get to your destination quickly.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the roadway is dry.
questions.explanation: Driving at excessive speeds is a major cause of fatal crashes. Never drive above the posted maximum speed limit and adjust your speed to fit conditions.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, be sure to:
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will usually continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerC: The trailer will likely swing around.
questions.explanation: A trailer tends to swing around, potentially resulting in a trailer jackknife, if its wheels lock up.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: Which part of a combination vehicle is the most likely to turn over?
questions.answerB: The trailer immediately behind the cab
questions.explanation: The "crack-the-whip" effect makes the last trailer in a combination the most likely to turn over. Be especially careful when operating a double or triple combination vehicle around a turn or corner.

questions.question: When driving in heavy traffic, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your cell phone for texting instead of calling.
questions.answerD: Turn up the ringer on your cell phone.
questions.explanation: Areas with heavy traffic, road construction, large numbers of pedestrians, or severe weather demand extra attention from a driver. The driver should avoid all possible distractions while in such areas, including cell phone use.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.answerD: A minute of hitting the brakes.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: When backing, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the passenger’s side mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn toward the passenger’s side whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: Why are roads especially slippery right after it begins to rain?
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerC: Gravel often gets washed to the middle of the lane.
questions.answerD: Tires are not usually designed to drive in rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, roads are often at their most slippery when the rain first begins to fall. Fresh rainwater mixes with oil and grease on the road to form a slick film. As the rain continues, this mixture will eventually wash away.

questions.question: To make it as safe as possible to leave a stop, you should park:
questions.answerA: So that you must back up to leave your parking space.
questions.answerB: So that you can pull forward to leave your parking space.
questions.answerC: On the side of a roadway, not in a parking lot.
questions.answerD: By backing into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Backing can be dangerous, so avoid doing it whenever you can. If possible, park in such a way that allows you to pull forward to exit your parking space.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will usually continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerC: The trailer will likely swing around.
questions.explanation: A trailer tends to swing around, potentially resulting in a trailer jackknife, if its wheels lock up.

questions.question: If you identify a distracted driver on the road, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter a distracted driver, make sure to give them plenty of room. Be very careful if you pass their vehicle because the driver may be unaware of your presence and drift into your lane.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: Eating while driving:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to maximize time.
questions.answerC: Creates a distraction for the driver.
questions.answerD: Is mandatory so cargo is not left unsupervised.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of driving distracted, you should avoid eating, drinking, or smoking while driving. Anything that diverts attention from the task of driving is a distraction.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: There may be extra weight in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything behind your vehicle. If you must drive in reverse, use a helper, if possible.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: One function of the emergency air line is to:
questions.answerB: Flash when air pressure is below a certain psi.
questions.answerD: Control the ability to maneuver during bad weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: If something is found to be unsafe during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue with the trip and make an appointment with a mechanic after the trip is completed.
questions.answerB: Let a more experienced driver use the truck.
questions.answerD: Not use the items found to be unsafe, but may continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals anything unsafe about your vehicle, you must get it repaired. It is illegal to operate an unsafe vehicle.

questions.question: Driving a combination vehicle ____ than driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving a combination vehicle usually requires more skill than driving a single vehicle. Combination vehicles are generally longer and heavier than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.answerD: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Doubles and triples:
questions.answerA: Turn easily due to their centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Are more difficult to turn than smaller commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Due to their size, doubles and triples cannot be turned suddenly. They require extra care to avoid rollovers when turning.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: When using a turn signal, you should not:
questions.answerC: Cancel the turn signal after completing the turn.
questions.answerD: Allow the turn signal to stay on long after the turn has been completed.
questions.explanation: Always signal well ahead of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously until you have completed the turn or lane change, then be sure to cancel the signal so you do not confuse other drivers.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as a fire extinguisher, is:
questions.answerA: Only needed for vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: If your trailer starts to skid while you are braking, you should release the brakes and allow them to begin to regain traction. Once its wheels have regained their grip on the road, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the tractor.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: A driver needs a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to transport hazardous materials in:
questions.answerA: A vehicle requiring a Class A license.
questions.answerB: A vehicle requiring a Class B license.
questions.answerC: A vehicle requiring a Class C license.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: If carrying a heavy load that is slowing you down, you should:
questions.answerD: Keep the vehicle in second gear.
questions.explanation: The right lanes of a roadway are generally intended for vehicles traveling more slowly than surrounding traffic. If being slowed down by a heavy load, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: If a tire rim is damaged, it should be:
questions.answerD: Put on the axle farthest from the driver.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are not safe.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be kept in the vehicle?
questions.answerA: A phone with emergency numbers programmed
questions.explanation: A driver transporting chlorine in cargo tanks must keep an approved gas mask and an emergency kit in their vehicle.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Be sure you are always driving so your vehicle can stop:
questions.answerA: Within 10 feet of your current position.
questions.answerB: Within 1,000 feet of your current position.
questions.answerC: Within your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be sure that you are driving in a manner that will allow your vehicle to come to a complete stop, if necessary, within the area of the road ahead that you are able to see.

questions.question: Multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions are used:
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle run more smoothly.
questions.answerD: To make a vehicle less noisy.
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears. They are usually controlled by a selector knob on the gearshift lever.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a tire problem to check for and avoid?
questions.answerA: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerB: Recapped tires on the front of a school bus
questions.answerD: All tires are made by the same company
questions.explanation: During an inspection, there are a number of tire problems to check for and avoid. Look for air pressure that is too low or too high; excessive wear; cuts or other damage; tread separation; dual tires that come into contact with each other or other parts of the vehicle; mismatched tire sizes; radial and bias-ply tires used together; cut or cracked valve stems; and regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires on the front wheels of a school bus.

questions.question: A vehicle should be equipped with all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Warning devices for parked vehicles, such as flares.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicles should always carry the proper emergency equipment. Be sure your vehicle is equipped with at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses, unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers; and warning devices for parked vehicles, such as warning triangles, fuses, or liquid burning flares.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: Always downshift before entering a curve. Decreasing your speed before entering the curve will allow you to maintain better control over the vehicle throughout the curve.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerC: Brake as you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.answerD: Brake with less force than you would in a vehicle not equipped with ABS.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination that is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would if the vehicle was not equipped with ABS.

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.
