questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down extra quickly.
questions.explanation: Air expands as it gets warmer, so the air pressure in your tires could reach dangerously high levels while being used in very hot weather. If this happens, stop and let your tires cool. Do not let air out of the tires, as this could result in the pressure dropping to an unsafe level once the tires cool down.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerB: Are equipped in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce normal braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: ABS is equipped in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and it neither increases nor decreases the vehicle's braking capability. ABS activates during hard applications of the brake pedal in order to prevent wheels from locking up.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be placed:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows access to all emergency exits.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave items in the aisle or doorways of the bus. All baggage and cargo must be secured in a manner that will allow passengers to exit the bus by any door or window in the event of an emergency.

questions.question: When a tire goes flat, you may hear a loud bang. The truck will be affected:
questions.answerC: Only if the damaged tire is near the front of the truck.
questions.answerD: Only if the truck is hauling a load.
questions.explanation: There may be a delay of a few seconds between the sound of a tire failing and the time that the vehicle is affected by the tire failure. Because of the short delay, a driver may initially believe that the sound came from another vehicle.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.answerD: Putting your hand out the driver's side window and waving.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: One way to overcome the challenges of blind spots is to:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding vehicles so no other drivers can pass you.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, allowing you to only worry about vehicles to your right.
questions.answerC: Make frequent mirror checks and assess the positions of surrounding vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should make frequent mirror checks to monitor the traffic around you. This should help you notice if surrounding vehicles begin to move into your blind spots.

questions.question: If a vehicle is found to be over-length during a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Trim the length of the load.
questions.answerC: Ensure flags and lights indicating the oversize load are fastened securely.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals a load to be oversize, the driver must confirm that all required signs, flags, lamps, and reflectors are safely and properly mounted, and that and all required permits are in their possession.

questions.question: Buses must never carry ____ in the space occupied by passengers.
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in the area occupied by passengers.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using flashing lights so other road users move out of your path.
questions.answerC: Drive at a safe speed and arrive when you arrive.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in dangerous and aggressive driving behavior, you should relax and accept any delays that arise throughout a trip. To help avoid the stress of arriving late to a destination, plan for likely delays when planning your drive.

questions.question: When you are driving while drowsy, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and try to finish the trip.
questions.explanation: The only effective way to deal with drowsiness while driving is to stop and sleep. Caffeine or other stimulant drugs may help you stay awake, but they will not keep you alert. You will likely end up being even more tired when the artificial stimulants begin to wear off.

questions.question: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove your foot from the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn quickly in the direction of the skid.
questions.answerC: Countersteer after the vehicle is back on course.
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove your foot from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: When encountering fog, you will be safest if you:
questions.answerD: Follow the vehicle ahead of you closely.
questions.explanation: Fog can quickly deteriorate drivers' ability to see the road, other drivers, and other hazards. Avoid driving in fog if at all possible.

questions.question: Regarding winter driving, all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: Front tires should have a tread depth of at least 4/32 an inch.
questions.answerC: Rear tires should have a tread depth of at least 2/32 an inch.
questions.answerD: Use a gauge to verify that each tire has a safe tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is particularly important that your tires have adequate tread. You need a tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch on the back tires. Check the tread depths by using a gauge.

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good rule to follow when making a turn?
questions.answerB: Use your arms to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Turn off your turn signal before entering the turn to avoid confusing other drivers.
questions.explanation: Signal well in advance of a turn so drivers behind you are aware of your intentions. Keep the signal on throughout the turn and turn it off once the turn is complete.

questions.question: The emergency exit door:
questions.answerA: Can be opened if the bus becomes too hot while being driven.
questions.answerB: Can be opened while the bus is being driven if the bus is carrying cargo.
questions.answerC: Can be opened to provide a better view while the bus is being backed.
questions.answerD: Should never be open while the bus is being driven.
questions.explanation: Check all emergency exits before operating a bus. Never drive a bus with an open emergency exit door or window.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to another person in a vehicle
questions.answerB: Children on the side of the road
questions.answerC: Construction workers on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Drivers who are holding conversations with others may not be paying full attention to the road and may make unsafe moves. Children do not always pay attention to traffic and may dart into the road without looking. Exercise caution when driving near road workers. This helps to keep the workers and other distracted drivers safe.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter the cab due to:
questions.answerB: The wrong type of fuel being used.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, release the accelerator and push in the clutch. This will slow down your vehicle and help it regain traction.

questions.question: Buses must never carry:
questions.answerB: Any amount of solid Class 6 poisons.
questions.explanation: Buses may never be used to transport radioactive materials. Division 2.3 poison gas, liquid Class 6 poisons, tear gas, and irritating materials are also not permitted to be carried by bus.

questions.question: When making a turn, when should you cancel your turn signal?
questions.answerB: In the middle of the turn
questions.explanation: When turning or changing lanes, you should signal early and signal continuously. Cancel your turn signal once the turn or lane change is complete.

questions.question: Buses may carry:
questions.answerD: Explosives other than small arms ammunition.
questions.explanation: Small arms ammunition labeled ORM-D, emergency hospital supplies, and drugs are permitted to be transported by bus. Most other kinds of hazardous materials may not be carried on buses.

questions.question: To best reduce the distractions of a cell phone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay on a single call for an entire trip.
questions.answerB: Turn the phone off before driving.
questions.answerC: Only us the phone to accept incoming calls.
questions.answerD: Use the phone to text rather than talk.
questions.explanation: If possible, you should avoid all cell phone distractions by turning it off before starting a trip and leaving it off until you reach your destination.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Always comes as a result of physical distraction, not mental distraction.
questions.answerB: Can be elevated by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerD: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations while driving.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of distraction, do not engage in complex or emotionally intense conversations while driving. Pre-programming radio stations before your trip and avoiding eating, drinking, or smoking while at the wheel can also help you avoid becoming distracted while driving. Remember that mental distractions that take your attention away from the task of driving can be just as dangerous as physical distractions.

questions.question: Off-ramps:
questions.answerC: Should not be used by trucks.
questions.answerD: Should be used only if following another vehicle.
questions.explanation: The combination of slopes and curves can make freeway on- and off-ramps dangerous for trucks. Remember that posted speed limits on ramps may be safe to be driven by cars but too fast to be driven by large or heavily-loaded vehicles.

questions.question: Which of the following indicates drowsy driving?
questions.answerA: Eyes going out of focus by themselves
questions.answerB: Having trouble keeping your head up
questions.explanation: Indicators of drowsiness while driving include your eyes closing or going out of focus by themselves, having trouble keeping your head up, and drifting between lanes.

questions.question: Move over laws require:
questions.answerA: Trucks to use the left lane.
questions.answerB: All vehicles to vacate the lane closest to an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing.
questions.answerC: All vehicles to use the left lane.
questions.answerD: All vehicles to move to the left lane if a flatbed trailer is in the right lane.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with its lights on is stopped on the side of the road, move over laws require drivers to vacate the lane directly next to the vehicle, if possible. If a driver cannot move over safely, they must slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: Baggage and freight should be stored in a way that:
questions.answerA: Allows passengers to easily see the items.
questions.answerB: Protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.
questions.answerC: Keeps the items in the aisle without shifting.
questions.explanation: On a bus, baggage and freight must be stored in a way that allows the driver to move freely and easily; allows passengers to exit via any window or door in the event of an emergency; and protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: Allow the rear wheels to lock up
questions.answerB: Allow all wheels to lock up
questions.answerD: Alert other motorists when you are braking
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When checking the engine compartment:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should not be engaged.
questions.answerD: The gearshift should be in first gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting the engine compartment, make sure that the parking brakes are on and/or the wheels are chocked. Check the engine compartment before entering the cab and starting the engine.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: If hydraulic brakes fail, a driver can reduce their speed by:
questions.answerD: Letting the truck run out of gas.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic bakes fail, shifting into a lower gear can help slow your vehicle down.

questions.question: When steering to avoid a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use one hand to steer.
questions.answerB: Keep both hands on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Not use your mirrors to check other lanes.
questions.answerD: Speed up as you get nearer to the hazard.
questions.explanation: When turning quickly to avoid colliding with a hazard in the roadway, you should always keep both hands on the steering wheel. You must have a firm grip on the wheel to be able to turn quickly.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: If a driver begins to feel fatigued while driving, they should:
questions.answerD: Drive faster to finish the trip more quickly.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the only safe response is to safely leave the road and get some sleep. Using artificial stimulants can be dangerous because they may cause extreme fatigue when they begin to wear off.

questions.question: After starting the engine, oil pressure should reach a normal level:
questions.explanation: After you start the engine, keep an eye on the gauges. Oil pressure should rise to a normal level within a few seconds of the engine being started.

questions.question: During a bus ride:
questions.answerA: Carry-on baggage may be kept in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Passengers may sit in the aisle.
questions.answerC: Aisles must remain free of obstacles.
questions.answerD: Items may be placed in the aisle if passengers could easily step over them.
questions.explanation: Do not allow riders to leave carry-on baggage in any doorway or aisle. There should be nothing in the aisle that might trip other riders. Secure baggage in a way that prevents damage.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to another person in a vehicle
questions.answerB: Children on the side of the road
questions.answerC: Construction workers on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Drivers who are holding conversations with others may not be paying full attention to the road and may make unsafe moves. Children do not always pay attention to traffic and may dart into the road without looking. Exercise caution when driving near road workers. This helps to keep the workers and other distracted drivers safe.

questions.question: If feeling tired and frequently yawning, you should:
questions.answerD: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: Frequent yawning is a warning sign of fatigue. If you become tired while driving, the only safe response is to stop and get some sleep. You cannot rely on artificial stimulants, like caffeine, to keep you alert because they will eventually wear off and leave you more tired than you originally were.

questions.question: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Plan trips without allocating extra time for traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly in the left lane.
questions.answerD: Not make gestures to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming an aggressive driver, begin a trip with realistic expectations of how long the trip will take, allowing extra time for traffic delays. Do not tailgate other vehicles. To avoid upsetting other drivers, do not drive slowly in the left lane and do not gesture at the drivers (even in seemingly minor ways, like shaking your head).

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get across the tracks as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Roll your window down to listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Never try to outdrive an approaching train.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed as you approach a railroad crossing. Remember that you will not necessarily be able to hear a train, and don't assume that signals will warn you of its approach. Never try to outdrive an approaching train at a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.answerD: Put on your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Dollies equipped with ABS are required to have malfunction lamps located where?
questions.explanation: A dolly equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is required to have a yellow malfunction lamp located on its left side.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Applying the brake pedal causes air pressure to activate an electric switch and:
questions.answerB: Turn on the low pressure warning light.
questions.answerD: Turn off the low pressure warning light.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: What can happen if a parking brake is used in very wet weather when temperatures are below freezing?
questions.answerB: The brakes may freeze so the vehicle cannot move.
questions.answerC: The brakes may suddenly release by themselves.
questions.explanation: If you use the parking brakes when the weather is very wet and the temperature is below freezing, the brakes may become frozen, preventing the vehicle from moving.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: The air entering air storage tanks may contain:
questions.explanation: The air that enters air storage tanks in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. Because accumulations of these materials can damage the braking system, tanks are equipped with drains to allow their removal.

questions.question: How is water and compressor oil removed from the bottom of an air storage tank?
questions.answerA: The water and oil are siphoned out of the tank.
questions.answerB: A drain valve is opened to remove the water and oil from the tank.
questions.answerC: The water and oil are removed automatically as the brakes are used.
questions.answerD: A sponge is used to soak up the water and oil.
questions.explanation: Water and compressor oil are removed from air storage tanks through a drain valve. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated tanks must be drained every day to remove this build-up.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait to begin driving until the air compressor builds up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: If using air tanks with manually operated drains, how often should you drain the tanks?
questions.explanation: To prevent the build up of oil and water in a vehicle's air tanks, manually operated air tank drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Remove the drum and look inside.
questions.answerD: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: On a truck with air brakes, the braking system’s air compressor:
questions.answerA: Pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: When using the controlled braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes with about half of your usual force.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes so the wheels lock.
questions.answerD: Apply the brakes with minimal pressure.
questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Before starting down a hill, be sure to:
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: Dollies equipped with ABS are required to have malfunction lamps located where?
questions.explanation: A dolly equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is required to have a yellow malfunction lamp located on its left side.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Remove the drum and look inside.
questions.answerD: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: When the brake pedal is pushed down, air brakes work:
questions.answerD: Only if it is warm outside.
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual brake system, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Wait to begin driving until the air compressor builds up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.answerD: Pump the pedal about 20 times to build pressure, then begin driving.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum pressure of 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.answerD: Releases air from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer is equipped with ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Try driving on a slippery surface and see if ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: Trailers and converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). This will be indicated by the presence of a yellow malfunction lamp. You can determine if older trailers have ABS by checking under the trailers for ECU and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: When uncoupling a trailer, landing gear should be:
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. When uncoupling, landing gear should be lowered to make firm contact with the ground. If a trailer is loaded when it is being uncoupled, you should lower the landing gear and turn the crank a few additional times to remove some weight from the trailer.

questions.question: What does the trailer air supply control look like?
questions.answerA: It is a square blue knob.
questions.answerB: It is a triangular yellow knob.
questions.answerC: It is an eight-sided red knob.
questions.answerD: It is a circular orange knob.
questions.explanation: On newer vehicles, the trailer air supply control is an eight-sided red knob. It's used to control the tractor protection valve.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: One way to prevent a rollover is to:
questions.answerA: Move cargo to the left side of the rig.
questions.answerB: Keep cargo centered on the rig.
questions.answerC: Move cargo to the right side of the rig.
questions.answerD: Keep cargo as far from the ground as possible.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: A trailer will be most likely to swing around when:
questions.explanation: An empty trailer will require a longer stopping distance than a loaded trailer. Additionally, a trailer is most likely to swing out and strike other vehicles when it is lightly loaded or empty.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.question: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerC: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will permit you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand brake while experiencing a trailer jackknife will:
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a trailer jackknife, you can help your tires regain traction by releasing the brakes. Using a trailer hand brake while experiencing a skid will only cause the skid to continue.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: One function of the emergency air line is to:
questions.answerB: Flash when air pressure is below a certain psi.
questions.answerD: Control the ability to maneuver during bad weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The turn should be made as tightly as possible.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels move in different paths.
questions.answerC: The rear wheels should run over the curb.
questions.answerD: It is acceptable for street signs to be knocked over if they are too close to the road.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: When driving a tractor-trailer equipped with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop harder than you would otherwise.
questions.answerB: Use extra braking force to ensure the ABS kicks in.
questions.answerD: Brake using less pressure than you would otherwise use.
questions.explanation: When driving a tractor-trailer combination equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should brake in the same manner that you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: A trailer will be most likely to swing around when:
questions.explanation: An empty trailer will require a longer stopping distance than a loaded trailer. Additionally, a trailer is most likely to swing out and strike other vehicles when it is lightly loaded or empty.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue the backing process without changing anything.
questions.answerB: Pull the truck forward, readjust, and start backing again.
questions.answerC: Get out of the truck and move the trailer into the right position.
questions.answerD: Turn the steering wheel all the way to the left until the trailer straightens out.
questions.explanation: If your trailer goes off course while you are backing, you should pull your truck forward and reposition your vehicle as needed before continuing to back up.

questions.question: What is a tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve to keep air in the brake system should there be a bad leak
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the truck from being stolen
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the driver from going too fast
questions.answerD: A valve that prevents the trailer from accidentally being released
questions.explanation: In a combination vehicle with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system in the event of the trailer breaking away or developing a leak.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: Air pressure in the ____ air line is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake.
questions.explanation: Air pressure in the service air line is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is also known as the control line or signal line. This line is connected to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied more quickly than would otherwise be possible.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: The service air line is attached to the:
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: ____ are the cause of more than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths.
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.answerD: Pulling off the road and waiting when there is high traffic.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: After coupling, there should be ____ between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: A shut-off valve:
questions.answerA: Is located on the front of a trailer.
questions.answerB: Is located on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: Prevents air from escaping an air brake system.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.answerD: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.
